title: Real Estate Brokerage Reviews You Can Actually Trust
excerpt: Key Points: Anonymous agent reviews > brand hype – Skip the PR spin; Glassdoor/Reddit tell the real story. High fees & splits bleed profits – Compass, Corcoran,…
content:
Key Points:

  • Anonymous agent reviews > brand hype – Skip the PR spin; Glassdoor/Reddit tell the real story.
  • High fees & splits bleed profits – Compass, Corcoran, and Sotheby’s charge luxury prices for basic support.
  • Leads? You’re on your own – Most brokerages (RE/MAX, The Agency) offer tools, not clients.
  • Training ? consistent – Keller Williams excels; others leave you Googling “how to real estate.”
  • “Luxury” = steep costs – Prestige (Sotheby’s, Douglas Elliman) hides fees, competition, and outdated tech.
  • Work-life balance is a myth – Redfin’s salary = burnout; Compass demands hustle 24/7.
  • Top pick: eXp Realty – 4.5 stars, 92% agent approval, low fees, virtual tools, revenue share.
  • Skip the grind: Smart Agent Alliance – Pre-built lead gen, mentorship, marketing systems.

You know how Amazon lets you filter out the junk with reviews from real people? Yeah, we’re doing that—except this time, it’s not for air fryers or phone chargers. It’s for top real estate companies.

We’ve pulled together legit real estate brokerage reviews from agents who’ve actually worked at these firms. No marketing spin. No recruiter scripts. Just real talk from the inside—like having a brutally honest friend at every brokerage who’s more into truth bombs than team meetings.

Whether you’re hunting for the best real estate brokerage for new agents, curious about what is the most successful real estate company, or just trying to avoid signing on with the next Blockbuster-in-a-suit, this list has you covered. We did the research so you don’t have to. Here’s your handy dandy index:

Insider Feedback on 12 Top Brokerages: From Worst to First

Redfin – Structure, Salary, and a Side of Burnout

Douglas Elliman – Prestige, Perks, and a Few Cracks in the Foundation

The Agency – Luxury Cool, But Bring Your Own Leads (and Maybe a Therapist)

Century 21 – Family Vibes, Franchise Fees, and a Familiar Story

Coldwell Banker – Big Brand, Big Tools… Bring Your Own Patience

RE/MAX – Big Brand, Big Splits, Big Expectations

Corcoran – Polished, Prestigious, and Priced Like It

Berkshire Hathaway – Big Name, Bigger Expectations

Sotheby’s – Luxury Brand, High Standards, and You’d Better Show Up Ready

Keller Williams – The Training Champ (With a Side of DIY Business Building)

eXp Realty – The Cloud-Based Powerhouse Agents Actually Recommend

Why Smart Agent Alliance Is the Shortcut to the Brokerage Support You Actually Want
Frequently Asked Questions

Choosing the Right Brokerage: It’s Not Just About the Splits

Picking a brokerage isn’t about who has the flashiest promo video. It’s about finding a company that won’t leave you broke, burned out, or buried under empty promises.

Sure, you’ll compare commission splits, fees, and how the tech stacks up. Something you can easily do with our brokerage comparison tool. But don’t stop there. The real differentiators? Things like stock incentives, lead systems, mentorship, training that doesn’t suck, and whether someone actually answers when you need support. Spoiler alert: not all of the top real estate brokerage companies deliver on those.

Want to know what questions to ask before making a move? Check out our blog, Top 17 Brokerage Interview Questions to Ask Before Choosing.

Ranking Criteria: Real Talk from Agents Who Don’t Sugarcoat

Let’s be honest—every brokerage has a glossy pitch deck. That’s why we went straight to the agents who’ve actually worked there and don’t have a script to follow.

We pulled anonymous agent reviews from Glassdoor and Reddit, where people tell it like it is. These platforms offer a look behind the curtain—no filters, no fear of getting cut from the company holiday party.

We used Glassdoor’s official rating system to rank the firms, so we’re not just winging it here. Whether you’re comparing the top 10 brokerage firms or checking out the eXp Realty reviews for new agents, this is the context you’ve been missing.

Now let’s talk about the pros… briefly. “Great flexibility,” “cool tech,” “supportive culture”—yeah, those show up everywhere. What matters more? The cons. The deal-breakers. The things people don’t say out loud during onboarding.

Because when it comes to real estate agent reviews, the one-star bombs often tell you way more than five-star fluff ever could. And if you’re sizing up the top real estate brokerages in the US, you need to know what could go wrong before you sign anything. While reviews reach into the past, know that brokerage profitability matters too because that is likely to define your future. So don’t miss our blog all about what are the top real estate companies by profitability.

Insider Feedback on 12 Top Brokerages: From Worst to First

Time to separate the hype from the helpful. We’re ranking 12 major real estate brokerage companies based on what actually matters—real estate brokerage reviews from agents who’ve worked there lived it, and left anonymous feedback without sugarcoating a thing.

These are unfiltered real estate agent reviews, covering the real pros, the ugly cons, and whether they’d actually recommend their brokerage to a friend. If two companies tied in rating, we broke the tie based on that “would-you-recommend” factor.

Trying to figure out which of the top real estate brokers in the USA are legit and which are just running on reputation? You’re about to find out.

Compass – Fancy Tech & Friendly Vibes

Compass pulls a 3.7 rating from over 2,000 real estate brokerage reviews, with 60% of agents saying they’d recommend it and 67% approving of the CEO. Solid, but not groundbreaking. That’s a dead-last agent ranking!

Agents consistently praise the tech, culture, and brand recognition—especially in luxury markets. The tools are sleek, the vibe is collaborative, and the Compass name does some heavy lifting with clients. Leadership and support also get a thumbs up, and agents like the freedom to manage their own schedules (although that exists at pretty much every brokerage).

But before you get too cozy, here’s the part that doesn’t show up on Glassdoor: Compass is the least profitable brokerage among all publicly traded firms. Yep—again, dead last. We break down the earnings disaster in our blog on brokerage profitability, but spoiler: even the branding can’t cover that kind of red ink.

The Compass Cons: When the Aesthetic Doesn’t Pay the Bills

Now for the part that really matters: the stuff agents complain about when no one from management is listening. Compass may get points for polish, but the real estate agent reviews make it clear—there are cracks behind the clean branding.

Here’s what’s consistently rubbing agents the wrong way:

  • High Fees and Rough Commission Splits
    • Compass isn’t cheap to hang your license. Agents frequently mention hefty monthly fees, confusing commission structures, and extra per-transaction costs that add up fast—especially for those not consistently closing deals. One agent put it bluntly: “Low split, then another 3% per deal? That’s annoying.”
  • No Leads, No Problem? Actually… It’s a Problem.
    • The brokerage may provide sleek tools, but the leads? Not so much. Reviews repeatedly call out the complete lack of company-generated business. Several agents said flat-out: “They don’t provide leads.”
  • High Pressure, Low Warm Fuzzies
    • Many reviews describe Compass as competitive and cutthroat—fine if you thrive on 24/7 hustle, less ideal if you were hoping for work-life balance. One agent described it as, “Just like every other brokerage that swears they’re the best.”
  • Team or Bust
    • Compass leans heavily on a team-based structure, which can leave solo agents feeling lost in the shuffle. Multiple reviews say that without a team, it’s hard to gain traction—and support from management feels nonexistent unless you’re already producing.
  • Corporate Vibes, Minus the Warmth
    • Despite the “cool” aesthetic, several agents described the office culture as cold and corporate. There’s a sense that higher-ups stay distant and agents can easily feel like just another headcount. One review summed it up: “Big company, low commission—get lost in the crowd.”

So while Compass earns its spot among the top real estate brokerage companies by name recognition and flash, the agent reviews suggest a different story: great surface-level shine, but some serious internal growing pains. If you’re not already a top producer with a team, the costs might just outweigh the perks.

Redfin – Structure, Salary, and a Side of Burnout

Redfin earns a 3.6 rating with 65% of agents recommending it to a friend and 79% approving of the CEO.

Redfin’s model is different from most of the top real estate brokerage companies. It’s not your typical 1099 commission-only gig. Agents often receive a base salary, benefits, and enjoy a collaborative team culture, making it feel more like a W-2 job with corporate perks.  Agents who like structure and teamwork tend to feel at home at Redfin. Reviews frequently highlight a collaborative culture, supportive coworkers, and management that doesn’t ghost you when things get tough. The ability to work from home, enjoy a flexible(ish) schedule, and earn a base salary with benefits gives it a corporate vibe—but in a way that some agents actually appreciate. And while the tech can be a lot, agents do give Redfin props for keeping things organized and efficient—at least when it’s working.

It sounds like a dream setup—until you scroll past the star ratings and into the actual complaints.

The Redfin Cons: Salary Stability Comes at a Cost

If Redfin feels more like a corporate job, that’s because… it kind of is. And the real estate agent reviews make it clear that stability often comes with strings.

  • Commission Caps & Pay Frustration
    • Many agents say the income potential just doesn’t cut it. While the base salary is nice for consistency, the commission structure is limited, and some agents feel they’re leaving money on the table compared to more traditional brokerages.
  • Weekend Burnout Is Real
    • Agents love the “flexibility”—until they realize it includes working most weekends and juggling a non-stop client load. Reviews call out a lack of real work-life balance due to the heavy volume and rigid expectations.
  • Clogged Career Paths
    • Looking to move up? Not so fast. Many agents feel like they hit a ceiling quickly, with few opportunities to advance or grow inside the company.
  • Too Many Clients, Too Little Time
    • That structured lead system? It can flood agents with more customers than they can handle, leading to burnout and customer service fatigue. As one review put it: “Great place to start, exhausting to maintain.”
  • Technology Overwhelm
    • Yes, Redfin has tech—but some agents say it’s overkill. The systems are clunky, CRMs could be better, and the constant updates can be more frustrating than helpful.

So if you’re someone who likes structure, salary, and teamwork, Redfin could feel like the best real estate brokerage for your needs. But if you’re after uncapped income, flexible growth, and control over your schedule, you may want to read between the lines—because these real estate reviews show that consistency comes at a cost.

Douglas Elliman – Prestige, Perks, and a Few Cracks in the Foundation

Douglas Elliman pulls a 3.8 with 67% of agents saying they’d recommend it to a friend, and a solid 88% CEO approval rating.

Agents rave about the brand prestige, strong training and support, and an office culture that leans collaborative. The company’s long-standing presence in luxury markets brings a level of clout that newer brokerages can’t fake. Add in a flexible schedule, a stash of resources, and seasoned leadership (depending on the office), and Douglas Elliman has its perks—especially if you’re newer and want exposure in high-end real estate.

The Douglas Elliman Cons: Fancy Brand, Familiar Problems

As far as top real estate brokerage companies go, Douglas Elliman gets respect—but not without its share of classic big-brokerage baggage.

  • Commission-Only Pay (and It’s Not Cheap to Stay)
    • Like many traditional brokerages, Elliman is 100% commission-based—so you eat what you kill. Agents also say the splits and monthly fees are steep, making it tough to get ahead unless you’re already producing at a high level. “There’s a price to pay for the resources,” one review noted.
  • Competitive & Hierarchical Vibes
    • Some offices feel like a team, others feel like high school—complete with cliques and top-producer favoritism. It’s a sink-or-swim environment where newer agents can easily feel sidelined.
  • Support Isn’t Always Consistent
    • Support varies widely by office and manager. While some managers are all-in, others are checked out—and if you don’t speak up or push for help, you may be left to figure it all out on your own.
  • Outdated Tech and Clunky Tools
    • Despite the brokerage’s luxury positioning, the technology doesn’t always match. Several agents called it outdated or non-intuitive, with too many disconnected systems and not enough streamlining.
  • Communication Gaps from the Top Down
    • While some managers are praised, others leave agents feeling ignored. Reviews mention inconsistent support, unclear expectations, and office politics that get in the way of productivity.

Bottom line? Douglas Elliman may be one of the top real estate brokers in the USA, but agents want the backend to match the brand. If you’re an experienced agent with a strong book of business and a taste for prestige, it could be a solid fit. But if you’re looking for hand-holding or innovation, don’t let the name fool you—it’s not always as polished behind the scenes.

The Agency – Luxury Cool, But Bring Your Own Leads (and Maybe a Therapist)

The Agency scores a strong 4.0 and the agent sentiment is sort of glowing—71% would recommend it to a friend, and 82% approve of the CEO.

The vibe here is sleek and supportive. Agents call out the collegial environment, solid CRM tools, marketing support, and a culture that feels more “work fam” than “corporate cult.” You get freedom and flexibility to build your business how you want—and if you’re already good at sales, this place can make you look (and feel) like a rockstar.

The Agency Cons: Great Vibe, but You’d Better Be Scrappy

Even with the fancy logo and good vibes, The Agency isn’t immune to the same issues that show up in real estate agent reviews across the board.

  • High Stress and Cutthroat Competition
    • Several reviews paint the job as a 24/7 hustle, with one calling it “very stressful”—not because of clients, but because of the pressure to constantly perform in a saturated market.
  • Management Drama and Favoritism
    • Not every manager is a team player. Some agents complain about poor communication, rude leadership, and even shady lead distribution, which feels more like Hunger Games than high-end real estate.
  • Quality Leads? Not Really a Thing Here
    • Multiple reviews say leads are sparse—and when they do come, they’re low-budget rentals or dead-end deals. Agents feel like they’re stuck sourcing their own business, which kind of defeats the purpose of having “support.”
  • Turnover and Team Instability
    • Behind the polished brand, there’s high turnover, inconsistent systems, and what sounds like some internal shakeups. Great culture only goes so far if you’re constantly rebuilding teams or training new managers.

So, is The Agency one of the best real estate brokerages for high-performing agents who want a luxury brand behind them? Possibly—if you’re self-motivated, already have a pipeline, and don’t mind dodging the occasional internal chaos. But if you’re looking for hand-delivered leads and a team that’s got your back 24/7… the reviews say you might be chasing a dream, not a done deal.

Century 21 – Family Vibes, Franchise Fees, and a Familiar Story

Century 21 pulls in a solid 4.1 rating with 74% of agents saying they’d recommend it to a friend and a whopping 89% CEO approval rating.

New agents especially shout out the training, support, and family-style culture. The vibe? Welcoming. The systems? Robust. The brand recognition? Still strong in a lot of markets. If you’re looking for a brokerage that feels like a good first step into real estate—with some hand-holding and a flexible schedule—Century 21 delivers a solid starting point.

The Century 21 Cons: Big Name, Big Splits, and Some Outdated Baggage

Century 21 might bring the warm fuzzies, but it also brings the usual old-school brokerage problems. And the real estate agent reviews don’t hold back.

  • High Fees and Splits
    • Agents say the commission splits are steep, especially early on—and some question why they’re still paying franchise fees like it’s 2004. One agent even called it “expensive, but worth it”—which doesn’t exactly scream scalable.
  • Tech That’s Trying Its Best
    • The tools and backend systems are there, but agents say they feel clunky or outdated. Too many logins, slow support, and not enough tech-savviness compared to more modern brokerages.
  • Leads? You’re on Your Own.
    • Unless you’re on a team or in a high-volume office, don’t expect leads to rain from the sky. Several agents noted the lack of company-generated business—and a need for more long-term support in building client pipelines.
  • Work-Life Balance? Depends on Your Definition
    • Real estate is demanding, sure—but agents here say the workload and weekend grind can make balance feel impossible. If you want your nights and weekends off, you might want to rethink.

So is Century 21 good for you? It depends. If you want structure, mentorship, and a company that still values relationship-building over buzzwords, it might be a good launchpad. But if you’re looking for modern tools, better splits, and lead generation support – legacy doesn’t always mean leverage.

Coldwell Banker – Big Brand, Big Tools… Bring Your Own Patience

Coldwell Banker scores a shiny 4.1 stars with 78% saying they’d recommend it to a friend and 86% giving the CEO a thumbs-up. It’s also been listed as a Best Place to Work in both 2022 and 2023—so, hey, they’ve got trophies to back it up.

What do agents actually like? Training gets an A+, especially if you’re new and need someone to tell you what a CRM even is. The company also dishes out solid brand recognition, tons of marketing tools, and a flexible schedule that lets you decide when to hustle (or hide). The culture is consistently called out as supportive and collaborative, with enough experienced agents around to make it feel like you’re not totally winging it.

The earning potential is there too—assuming you’re ready to work your tail off. It’s one of the top real estate brokerage companies for those who want big-league branding and have the drive to match.

Coldwell Banker Cons: Fees, Leads, and the “Figure-It-Out” Method

Here’s where Coldwell Banker gets dinged:

  • Fees That Feel a Bit… Much
    • Agents repeatedly mention high desk fees and commission splits that don’t always feel justified—especially for new agents still figuring out how to unlock the office printer.
  • New Agents? Good Luck Out There.
    • Unless you’ve got a mentor lined up or a lead-generating sidekick, support for new agents is hit-or-miss, and leads aren’t exactly being handed out like open house flyers.
  • Real Estate = Real Burnout
    • While flexibility is praised, the reality is many agents feel overworked and on call 24/7, with weekends and evenings regularly sacrificed on the altar of client convenience.
  • Self-Starter Required
    • You’ll hear it in nearly every real estate brokerage review: success here means being relentlessly self-motivated. If you’re waiting for a manager to swoop in and save you—you’ll be waiting a while.

So if you’re looking for prestige, training, and access to a mega-brand name—check. But if you’re hoping for generous support, a flood of leads, and low startup costs… you might want to read a few more real estate brokerage reviews before you jump in.

RE/MAX – Big Brand, Big Splits, Big Expectations

RE/MAX pulls in a solid 4.2 rating with 79% of agents saying they’d recommend it to a friend and 88% approving of the CEO.

Agents love the freedom to build their own schedule, the strong training, and the big-brand street cred. If you’re self-driven and love the idea of high commission potential (95/5 splits, anyone?), RE/MAX gives you the sandbox to build your empire. Just don’t expect anyone to bring the shovels—or the leads.

RE/MAX Cons: You’re the Boss… and the Entire Payroll Department

For all the love in the real estate agent reviews, there’s a healthy dose of “you’re on your own” energy too.

  • High Fees, Big Bills
    • Agents say the desk fees can be brutal, especially if you’re not on a top-tier plan. Between that and the splits, it’s not exactly a budget-friendly option for new agents finding their footing.
  • Success Depends on You—and the Zip Code
    • How well you do depends on your hustle and your geography. Agents in hot markets thrive. Others? Not so much. And since it’s all about franchises, experiences vary wildly from office to office.
  • New Agents, You’re on Thin Ice
    • Reviews repeatedly mention that new agents don’t get much support—no leads, no real onboarding, no hand-holding. You’ll need grit and Google just to survive the first six months.
  • Tech Growing Pains
    • Booj was apparently a nightmare (their word, not mine), and while they’ve switched to kvCORE, reviews still want better CRMs and more tech-savvy support.

So, is RE/MAX one of the best real estate brokerages for experienced agents who know how to generate their own business and want name recognition? Absolutely. But if you’re brand new and hoping someone will show you where the coffee is… well, good luck finding the break room.

Corcoran – Polished, Prestigious, and Priced Like It

Clocking in at a shiny 4.3 stars, Corcoran is one of the top-rated real estate brokerages in the US—at least according to its own agents. With 69% saying they’d recommend it to a friend, and a CEO approval rating at 89%.

Agents rave about Corcoran’s top-tier training, its prestigious brand reputation, and collaborative work culture. If you’re looking for the best real estate brokerage for new agents in the high-end market, Corcoran might just feel like a five-star hotel with a desk fee. There’s lots of flexibility, room for growth, and that “I’ve made it” feeling when you walk into one of their offices.

But All That Prestige Comes at a Price

Luxury has its downsides—and agents are quick to spill in the real estate brokerage reviews:

  • Splits That Make Your Calculator Cry
    • Agents regularly call out the high commission splits and fees, which are steep enough to make you wonder if the brand name is printed in gold leaf.
  • Support Drops Off After the Honeymoon Phase
    • The first few months are filled with champagne and check-ins… then it’s “good luck out there” unless you’re already killing it.
  • Tech That’s Still Catching Up to 2020
    • While the brand screams luxury, the technology screams “we’ll get there eventually”. Several reviews mention outdated platforms and a slow shift toward digital tools.
  • You’re on Your Own in a Competitive Arena
    • Corcoran’s vibe is definitely “swim with the sharks.” If you’re new or introverted, brace yourself—this is not a brokerage where hand-holding is part of the onboarding process.

If you’re a self-starter with a client list and a thing for luxury branding, Corcoran can offer you a strong platform and respected name. But if you’re looking for hand-holding, low fees, or built-in lead generation, these real estate brokerage reviews suggest you might want to swipe left and keep looking.

Berkshire Hathaway – Big Name, Bigger Expectations

With a strong 4.3 rating and 78% of agents say they’d recommend Berkshire Hathaway to a friend, and 98% approve of the CEO.

Agents love the strong training, recognizable brand, and resources galore—especially for newbies who want structure, and seasoned agents who want to sharpen their edge. It’s also one of the few top real estate brokerages in the US where you can feel like a pro from day one… assuming you can figure out where all the tools are hiding.

Berkshire Hathaway Cons: Big Brand, Big Fees, Bring Your Own Leads

As polished as the BHHS brand is, the real estate brokerage reviews pull back the curtain—and it’s not all gold-plated signs and Warren Buffett quotes.

  • Fees That Keep on Giving (to the Franchise)
    • Agents call out high commission splits and extra fees that eat into profits. The franchise love doesn’t come cheap, and it’s easy to feel like you’re splitting your check five ways before you even cash it.
  • Support? Only if You’re Already Crushing It
    • The support starts off strong, but many agents report it fades fast. Once your onboarding hugs are over, you may be left searching for leads (or answers) on your own.
  • Too Many Tools, Not Enough Streamlining
    • BHHS gets an A+ for having everything. But it’s also a bit of a scavenger hunt. Tools, resources, websites, platforms—they’re scattered like a deck of cards at a toddler’s tea party.
  • A Little Too Competitive (and Clicky)
    • It’s a competitive environment, and a few reviews hint at old-school hierarchies and the dreaded “good ol’ boys club” vibes. The vibe isn’t always inclusive, and agents feel it.

So, is Berkshire Hathaway one of the top 10 brokerage firms worth joining? If you’re organized, tech-savvy, and ready to make your own leads work harder than your commission split—yes. But if you’re expecting endless hand-holding and free leads, it may feel less like a financial powerhouse and more like a luxury label with an expensive price tag.

Sotheby’s – Luxury Brand, High Standards, and You’d Better Show Up Ready

Sotheby’s clocks in at a strong 4.3 rating where 74% would recommend it, and 89% give the CEO the thumbs up.

Agents love the global brand recognition, which comes with serious clout for landing luxury clients. Add in a collaborative culture, solid support, flexible scheduling, and plenty of training and growth opportunities, and it’s easy to see why agents speak highly of the experience—especially those already operating in affluent circles.

The Sotheby’s Cons: Beautiful Branding Doesn’t Pay the Bills

Sotheby’s may be one of the top real estate companies by reputation, but the real estate agent reviews remind us that luxury comes at a cost—and not just for the buyers.

  • High Fees and Royalty Cuts
    • Here’s the catch: that global brand? It’s not free. Agents mention steep commission splits and royalty fees, with one calling out the 6% branding tax as a bitter pill to swallow. Oh, and tack on hefty E&O fees while you’re at it.
  • Saturated Markets = Fierce Competition
    • Want to break into luxury? So does everyone else. Agents report a crowded, competitive field, making it tough for newbies to get traction—especially without robust lead support.
  • It’s All You, Baby
    • The reviews are clear: if you’re not self-motivated, you’ll drown. There’s minimal hand-holding, and agents say you’re expected to arrive with your own business, or build it fast with little help.
  • Admin and Tech Headaches
    • For a brand known for elegance, the backend systems can feel clunky and chaotic. Multiple reviews point to too many internal platforms and international coordination gaps that slow things down.

So is Sotheby’s the best real estate brokerage for agents eyeing the luxury lane? If you’ve already got the network, the polish, and the drive, the brand can absolutely elevate your business. But if you’re still figuring it out? Read the real estate brokerage reviews carefully—because while the logo’s fancy, the hustle is still very, very real.

Keller Williams – The Training Champ (With a Side of DIY Business Building)

Keller Williams pulls in a rock-solid 4.3 stars with 86% recommending it and 94% supporting the CEO.  KW also racks up workplace awards—earning a spot on the Best Places to Work list for eight years running. The brand clearly knows how to make agents feel supported, at least on paper.

So what’s the real scoop? Agents consistently rave about the top-tier training programs, supportive leadership, and flexible schedule. It’s especially popular among newbies looking for a real estate brokerage that actually teaches you something before throwing you to the wolves. Pair that with a strong mentorship culture and sky’s-the-limit earning potential, and you’ve got one of the top real estate brokerages in the US for getting started.

Where the KW Kool-Aid Runs a Bit Thin

Even with that glowing reputation, Keller Williams isn’t immune to the usual brokerage gripes. Here’s what the real estate brokerage reviews are throwing shade at:

  • Steep Fees and Splits
    • Agents say the caps and monthly fees can feel like death by a thousand deductions—especially painful if you’re not closing deals consistently.
  • No Lead Fairy
    • There’s no magical lead fountain here. New agents especially note that you’re mostly left to figure out where business comes from… and fast.
  • Office Politics and Culture Drift
    • While many offices feel like a family, others seem more like a high school lunchroom—cliques, cold vibes, and a whole lot of agents crammed into the same boat.

If you’re a self-starter who thrives with great training and is ready to hustle for your own leads, Keller Williams might be one of the best real estate brokerage companies to launch your career. The real estate agent reviews are clear—KW’s got the bones… but whether you build a mansion or a money pit is still up to you.

eXp Realty – The Cloud-Based Powerhouse Agents Actually Recommend

With a whopping 4.5-star rating, 92% of agents recommend it, and 96% approve of the CEO.  Plus eXp lands in the Best Places to Work streak that could make Google jealous, with eight straight years on the list and #7 for 2025. eXp Realty isn’t just one of the top real estate brokerage companies—it’s the top-rated one by quite a gap according to the agents living it.

If you’ve been sifting through real estate agent reviews looking for the best real estate brokerage for new agents, eXp Realty consistently lands near the top. Why? Because it’s got what a modern agent actually needs: flexibility, training, tech tools, community support, and that sweet, sweet revenue share.

Agents love the massive resource library, cutting-edge tech, and mentorship options. Add in total independence, a positive, collaborative vibe, and the chance to earn stock and passive income. Yeah, exp realty reviews aren’t just good—they’re glowing.

But Even the Top Dog Has Its Gaps

No brokerage is perfect, and exp reviews still serve up some constructive truth bombs:

  • No Brick-and-Mortar? No Buffer
    • Agents who crave a desk and water cooler chat might feel a bit untethered. The lack of a physical office takes some adjustment—though there are free office options if you miss humans.
  • Self-Starter or Self-Sabotager
    • eXp Realty is not here to babysit. If you need constant hand-holding and someone checking your homework, this probably isn’t your scene. It’s a freedom-first model—with more training than you’ll know what to do with—but it’s on you to show up and use it.
  • Mentorship Roulette
    • While many mentors are fantastic, the quality has been inconsistent in the past. The good news? The mentorship program is improving and you can change mentors if need be.
  • Tech Can Get Noisy
    • Yes, there’s tons of tech. No, not all of it is perfect. KVCore gets the most heat, with some agents wishing for an upgrade or more intuitive tools.

eXp Realty isn’t just the top real estate brokerage in the world according to many agents—it’s one of the few that actually acts like it. For the driven, tech-friendly, and independent agent who wants scalability, collaboration, and a legit path to passive income, eXp checks nearly every box. Why Your Brokerage Choice Matters

Picking a brokerage isn’t just about your commission splits—although that’s always a big deal. eXp Realty vs Douglas Elliman: Agent Satisfaction

Let’s start by looking at how satisfied agents are with each brokerage. Based on Glassdoor reviews, eXp Realty leads the pack with a 4.6-star rating, while Douglas Elliman comes in with a 3.9-star rating. eXp Realty vs Douglas Elliman: Brokerage Profitability

Why does brokerage profitability matter to you? Because if a brokerage is financially stable, it’s more likely to keep investing in its agents by offering better tools, more training, and stronger support. A struggling brokerage might start making decisions that hurt its agents, like cutting commissions or adding new fees.

Let’s talk about Douglas Elliman’s profitability. They’ve posted 13 quarters of earnings, with 7 quarters of losses, meaning they have a 46% profitability rate. Not the strongest track record.

In contrast, eXp Realty has posted 20 quarters of earnings, with only 5 quarters of losses,—giving them a 75% profitability rate. Even better, eXp Realty is the only publicly traded brokerage that’s been profitable for the last five years.

That financial stability means continuous improvements for agents and clients without sudden changes that hurt your bottom line. If you want the full scoop on brokerage profitability, check out our blog “Top Real Estate Companies That Might Go Under!”.

eXp Realty vs Douglas Elliman: Commission Splits

Let’s dive into the commission splits—arguably the most important factor for agents when choosing a brokerage.

At Douglas Elliman, commission splits range from 70/30 – 100/0 once you cap. However, the caps seem to be anywhere from $21,000 – $30,000 depending on the office. This wide variation makes it hard to predict exactly how much you’ll keep and how long it’ll take to cap, so make sure to ask for specifics during your interview.

At eXp Realty, it’s straightforward and agent-friendly. Every agent starts with an 80/20 split, and once you’ve paid $16,000 to the brokerage in a year, you move to 100% commission. Plus, eXp rewards agents with company stock for hitting certain milestones.

If you meet additional goals after capping, you can even get your $16,000 cap back in stock. At the end of the year, these agents will have earned more than 100% of their commission.

And with eXp Realty, every agent gets the same deal, whether you’re new to the game or a seasoned top producer. No negotiations are needed, and you know exactly what you’re getting from day one.

eXp Realty vs Douglas Elliman: E&O Insurance

When it comes to Errors and Omissions (E&O) insurance, this is where the details matter. Unfortunately, Douglas Elliman doesn’t provide much information on this, and agents are told to check with their local offices. Depending on your location, these fees could be significant, so make sure to clarify before signing up.

At eXp Realty, the E&O insurance is easy to understand. Agents only pay $60 per transaction, but once you hit $750 for the year, you’re done. No more E&O payments, no matter how many deals you close. This is a great setup for agents who want to avoid heavy upfront costs and only pay when they’re actually making money.

eXp Realty vs Douglas Elliman: Fees

Fees can really eat into your earnings, so let’s break down what each brokerage charges. At eXp Realty, agents pay a predictable $85 monthly fee and $25 per transaction until they hit their cap. It’s simple, straightforward, and budget-friendly.

At Douglas Elliman, fees vary by office, and agents are also subject to a 6% royalty fee per transaction. This means you’re paying a percentage of every deal, which can quickly add up, especially when combined with office fees.

eXp Realty vs Douglas Elliman: Training and Support

When it comes to training and support, you need a brokerage that’s got your back, whether you’re just starting out or looking to take your business to the next level.

At eXp Realty, the training and support are top-notch. They offer over 50 live training sessions every week, plus an extensive on-demand course library. New agents can jump into the Fast Start program, designed to help them start earning quickly, while more experienced agents can benefit from Kick Start program to level up their business.

On top of that, eXp provides 24/7 support and has over 2,000 full-time staff members ready to help out when you need it.

At Douglas Elliman, training and support can vary widely depending on the office. Some locations might offer great resources, while others may not provide much at all. The inconsistency means that your experience could be very different depending on where you work.

eXp Realty vs Douglas Elliman: Technology and Resources

In today’s real estate world, technology is critical, and having the right tools can make all the difference.

At eXp Realty, technology is a strong point. eXp is a fully virtual brokerage, and everything is done online through eXp World—from broker meetings to training sessions to client collaboration. Want the full scoop? Check out our blog on eXp World!

eXp Realty also provides agents with an IDX website, a kvCORE CRM, and a marketing center loaded with customizable templates, social media content, and much more. And the best part? eXp constantly updates and adds new tools to help agents stay ahead of the curve.

When it comes to Douglas Elliman, we couldn’t find much concrete information about the tech they offer agents. While there may be resources available, it’s unclear if there’s a standard set of tools across all offices. If you rely heavily on cutting-edge technology to run your business, eXp Realty’s setup gives you a clear advantage.

Why Douglas Elliman May Be Best for You

If you’re someone who prefers a traditional brokerage model with physical offices and enjoys face-to-face interactions, then Douglas Elliman could be a better fit. They have a well-established reputation and strong branding. Plus, if having a local office broker there to make sure you’re staying on task, Douglas Elliman may be the right choice.

However, if you’re just looking for out-of-home office space, eXp Realty provides FREE access to the 4,000 Regus office business lounges around the world. But if you’re someone who thrives in a structured environment with a local broker checking in regularly, Douglas Elliman might offer the kind of setup that works best for you.

eXp’s Exclusive Resources

Beyond the usual offerings, eXp Realty has a few game-changing features that other brokerages simply don’t provide. eXp Realty has a luxury division with global advertising around the world. eXp Realty has a dedicated team, Revenos, whose entire mission is to find and deliver top-quality leads directly to eXp agents—how great is that?

Then there’s eXp’s Referral tool that makes sending referrals to other agents effortless, and for those wanting to focus purely on referrals, eXp’s Referral Division slashes costs while keeping you active in the industry.

And, of course, there’s Revenue Share, which lets you build extra income by bringing other agents into eXp. The best part? That income doesn’t end when you retire and it’s willable, so it continues to roll in even after you’re no longer working. Now that’s a win-win!

That’s a Wrap

At the end of the day, comparing eXp Realty and Douglas Elliman comes down to your preferences. Douglas Elliman offers a traditional brokerage experience with physical offices, but higher fees and inconsistent support could be drawbacks.

eXp Realty gives agents transparent splits, lower fees, advanced tech, and 24/7 support—all of which can help you keep more of your earnings while growing your business. If you’re looking for flexibility and innovation, eXp Realty might just be the better choice for your real estate career.

At eXp Realty, the commission splits are refreshingly simple and transparent. Agents start with an 80/20 split, and once you’ve paid $16,000 to the brokerage in a year, you move to 100% commission for the rest of the year.

And with eXp, there’s no negotiation or confusion—every agent gets the same deal. Plus, eXp offers stock options for agents who hit certain milestones, so you can actually earn more than 100% of your commissions each year. Whether you’re a new agent or a top producer, the playing field is level at eXp.

E&O Insurance

Now let’s talk about Errors and Omissions (E&O) insurance. This is crucial for protecting both you and your brokerage from potential legal claims.

At Berkshire Hathaway, the details about E&O insurance are not widely shared, and it seems to vary by office. From what we’ve gathered, these costs can be substantial, so you’ll want to check with your local office to understand what you’ll be expected to pay.

At eXp Realty, agents pay $60 per transaction, and once you hit $750 for the year, your E&O fees stop. No more payments, no matter how many deals you close. This is a huge advantage, especially if you’re just starting out or want to keep more of your income in your pocket.

Fees

Fees can really add up, so let’s break down what to expect from eXp Realty and Berkshire Hathaway. At eXp Realty, agents pay a straightforward $85 monthly fee, and a $25 transaction fee per deal until you hit your cap. Pretty simple, right?

At Berkshire Hathaway, things are more complicated. Monthly fees can range from $295 to $625 per transaction, depending on your office. Plus, there’s a 6% royalty fee on each transaction, which can really start to add up. When you compare the two, eXp Realty offers a more predictable and cost-effective fee structure, which helps agents keep more of their earnings.

Training and Support

Training and support are key for both new agents and seasoned pros. Let’s see how these brokerages stack up. At eXp Realty, you’ll have access to over 50 live training sessions every week, along with a massive on-demand library of courses.

For new agents, the Fast Start program is designed to help you hit the ground running, while experienced agents can level up with the Kick Start program. And with 24/7 support and over 2,000 full-time staff members available to assist you, you’re never left hanging when you need help.

At Berkshire Hathaway, the training and support vary by office. Some offices might offer great resources, while others could leave you wanting more. Your experience will largely depend on your local office broker’s availability, which means you might not always have the support you need at crucial moments.

Technology and Resources

Having the right technology can make or break your real estate business, so let’s see how eXp Realty and Berkshire Hathaway compare.

eXp Realty is at the forefront of tech innovation with its fully virtual brokerage model. Agents work in eXp World, a metaverse-like platform where you can meet with brokers, get tech support, and attend training sessions. Want the full scoop? Check out our blog on eXp World!

Plus, eXp Realty provides agents with a personal IDX website, not just a page on your brokerage’s website, a powerful CRM & Lead Generator Tool, a Marketing Center filled with customizable templates and social media content, and more. And with eXp, the tech keeps evolving to help you stay ahead of the competition.

At Berkshire Hathaway, we found no information about their technology and resources. Not sure why, but it seems like a bad thing that no one is talking about it. If having access to cutting-edge tools and resources is crucial to your success, eXp Realty is the clear leader here.

Why Berkshire Hathaway May Be Best for You

While eXp Realty offers tons of benefits, Berkshire Hathaway may be the better fit if you prefer a traditional brokerage with physical offices. If you enjoy the structure of an office environment or need to have a local broker for face-to-face support and to crack the whip to get you moving, Berkshire Hathaway could be the right place for you.

But if you’re just looking for out-of-home office space, eXp Realty provides FREE access to over 4,000 Regus office business lounges around the world. But if you thrive in a more structured setting with daily in-person accountability, Berkshire Hathaway might feel more like home.

On top of everything else, eXp Realty offers a range of features that most other brokerages simply don’t. For luxury agents, eXp’s Luxury Division allows you to advertise your high-end listings globally, giving you top-tier exposure.

They also have a dedicated staff called Revenos, whose sole job is to find and provide quality leads directly to eXp agents—how cool is that? Their Referral tool makes it easy for agents to pass referrals to others with just a few clicks, and if you’re only interested in running a referral business, eXp’s Referral Division lowers costs while keeping you in the game.

And let’s not forget about Revenue Share, which offers agents a way to earn income by recommending other agents to join eXp. That income doesn’t stop when you retire and it’s willable, meaning it keeps giving even after you’re out of the game. Talk about a win-win!

content:

Why Your Brokerage Choice Matters

Your choice of brokerage isn’t just about your commission split—although, of course, that’s a major factor. But your brokerage also shapes your day-to-day experience, determines how much support you get, and dictates the resources you can access to grow your business. You need to choose a brokerage that helps you succeed while ensuring your bottom line stays healthy.

Today, we’re comparing eXp Realty and Coldwell Banker—two prominent names in real estate. We’ll explore everything from commission splits and fees to the level of training and agent satisfaction at each brokerage.

With eXp Realty, all the information is easily accessible, but with Coldwell Banker, we had to do some digging to find out what agents experience. No worries, we’ve got you covered.

eXp Realty vs Coldwell Banker: Agent Satisfaction

Let’s start by looking at how happy agents are at both brokerages. According to Glassdoor, eXp Realty stands strong with a 4.6-star rating, while Coldwell Banker also holds up well with a 4.3-star rating. These ratings give a snapshot of how agents feel about the support, resources, and overall experience at each company.

And as we all know, agents who are satisfied with their brokerage tend to be more successful.  If you’re curious about how the top real estate firms stack up, check out our blog “12 Insider Picks for the Best Real Estate Brokerage in 2024!”. Spoiler alert: eXp Realty ranks #1 on Glassdoor.

eXp Realty vs Coldwell Banker: Brokerage Profitability

Why should you care if your brokerage is making money? Because a profitable brokerage has the financial stability to offer better tools, resources, and fewer surprise changes that could hurt you or your clients.

Coldwell Banker is part of Anywhere Real Estate, which also owns big names like Sotheby’s, Better Homes & Gardens, Century 21, and Corcoran. Anywhere has posted 20 quarters of earnings, with 8 unprofitable quarters. That gives it a 60% profitability rate—not bad, but there’s definitely room for improvement.

Now let’s look at eXp Realty. They’ve posted 20 quarters of earnings, and 15 of those have been profitable, giving them a 75% profitability rate. What’s more, eXp Realty is the only publicly traded brokerage that’s been profitable over the past five years.

That stability translates to continuous improvements for both agents and clients. When you work at a brokerage that’s making money, they can afford to reinvest in their agents with better tools, training, and tech. If you want the full scoop on brokerage profitability, check out our blog “Top Real Estate Companies That Might Go Under!”.

eXp Realty vs Coldwell Banker: Commission Splits

Time to talk about commission splits—probably the first thing most agents look at when comparing brokerages. Coldwell Banker has a commission structure that varies widely depending on your office, location, and how you negotiate.

Splits range from 55/45 to 90/10, so that’s 55% to you and 45% to the brokerage at the lower end of the spectrum. Our research shows that the actual numbers vary a lot, so make sure to ask for specifics when you interview.

Now, eXp Realty is refreshingly simple. Every agent starts at an 80/20 split, and once you’ve paid $16,000 to eXp in the year, you cap, meaning you keep 100% of your commissions after that. There’s no negotiating for a better split—every agent gets the same deal, whether you’re new or a seasoned pro.

Plus, eXp offers opportunities to earn stock. You get company stock for hitting certain milestones, and if you hit additional goals after capping, you can earn your $16,000 cap back in stock. That’s how some agents actually earn more than 100% of their commission each year. Nice!

eXp Realty vs Coldwell Banker: E&O Insurance

Errors and Omissions (E&O) insurance is a must-have for agents, but how brokerages handle this cost varies. At Coldwell Banker, agents pay around $300 per month for E&O insurance. Whether that’s upfront or paid over time depends on the office, but that’s a significant cost no matter how you slice it.

At eXp Realty, E&O insurance is a lot more manageable. Agents only pay $60 per transaction, and eXp caps those fees at $750 annually. So once you’ve paid $750 in E&O for the year, you’re done. You won’t have to pay another penny, no matter how many deals you close. That’s a huge benefit for agents who are just getting started and don’t want to be burdened with hefty upfront costs.

eXp Realty vs Coldwell Banker: Fees

Fees are another critical consideration, and Coldwell Banker and eXp Realty handle them quite differently.

At eXp Realty, the fee structure is straightforward. Agents pay an $85 monthly fee and $25 per transaction until they hit their cap. It’s predictable, easy to understand, and there are no surprises.

Coldwell Banker’s fees, however, vary greatly depending on the office. Agents can expect to pay between $122 – $350 per month just to stay on board, and there’s also a 5% to 6.5% royalty fee charged per transaction. These fees can really add up and take a bigger chunk out of your earnings compared to eXp’s much simpler structure.

Between the clear fee structure at eXp and the variable, sometimes high, costs at Coldwell Banker, eXp Realty definitely offers a more agent-friendly deal when it comes to fees.

eXp Realty vs Coldwell Banker: Training and Support

Next up is training and support, which are crucial to helping agents, whether new or experienced, succeed.

At eXp Realty, the training opportunities are top-notch. With over 50 live training sessions every week, plus a full library of on-demand courses, there’s always something to help you improve. eXp also has programs like Fast Start for new agents who want to get going fast, and Kick Start for experienced agents looking to take their business to the next level.

On top of all that, eXp provides 24/7 support and over 2,000 full-time staff members to assist you with your needs.

Coldwell Banker, on the other hand, doesn’t offer a standardized training program across all offices. Training varies depending on where you’re located and what your office offers. That’s also true for agent support—it’s heavily reliant on the office broker, meaning your experience can vary depending on how available or helpful your broker is.

Technology and Resources

When it comes to tech, eXp Realty stands out from the crowd. They’ve built a fully virtual brokerage, and agents can do everything from meeting with brokers to attending training sessions in eXp World, their online metaverse-style platform. Want the full scoop? Check out our blog on eXp World!

Beyond that, eXp agents get access to an IDX website, a CRM called kvCORE, and a marketing center with customizable templates, social media content, and more. eXp is constantly adding new tech tools to help agents stay ahead of the game.

Unfortunately, we couldn’t dig up too much information about what Coldwell Banker offers in terms of tech. It’s unclear if they have any standard tools across offices, so ask about that during your Coldwell Banker interview.

Why Coldwell Banker May Be Best for You

If you’re someone who likes a more traditional office environment with face-to-face interactions and you prefer having a local office broker for day-to-day support, Coldwell Banker could be a better fit. They’ve got a long-standing reputation and strong branding, and for some agents, having that in-person accountability is key to their success.

However, if you’re just looking for out-of-home office space, eXp Realty provides FREE access to the 4,000 Regus office business lounges around the world. But that won’t be enough if you’re someone who needs the structure of a physical office, with a broker cracking the whip. If that’s the case, Coldwell Banker might feel more like home.

eXp’s Exclusive Resources

Beyond the usual offerings, eXp Realty has a few game-changing features that other brokerages simply don’t provide. eXp Realty has a dedicated team, Revenos, whose entire mission is to find and deliver top-quality leads directly to eXp agents—how great is that?

Then there’s eXp’s Referral tool that makes sending referrals to other agents effortless, and for those wanting to focus purely on referrals, eXp’s Referral Division slashes costs while keeping you active in the industry.

And, of course, there’s Revenue Share, which lets you build extra income by bringing other agents into eXp. The best part? That income doesn’t end when you retire and it’s willable, so it continues to roll in even after you’re no longer working. Now that’s a win-win!

That’s a Wrap

At the end of the day, when comparing eXp Realty and Coldwell Banker, it comes down to what kind of environment you thrive in. Coldwell Banker has the prestige of a traditional office setting, but with higher fees and less predictable splits, it might not be the most cost-effective option.

On the other hand, eXp Realty offers transparent splits, lower fees, better tech, and 24/7 support—all of which can help you keep more of your earnings and grow your business faster.

 On top of that, eXp Realty provides agents with their own IDX website, a powerful kvCORE CRM, and a marketing center with customizable templates for social media, flyers, and so much more.

There’s no virtual platform like eXp World, so if cutting-edge tech is something you value, eXp Realty is the better choice.

Why Redfin May Be Best for You

While eXp Realty offers a ton of value, Redfin still has its appeal, especially if you’re someone who values stability and enjoys a more traditional real estate model.

Redfin’s salary option offers consistency that might be appealing to agents who want a guaranteed paycheck, even if it comes with a lower commission split. Plus, if you prefer working in a more structured environment, where someone is in charge of keeping you on track, Redfin’s office-based approach could be a better fit for you.

That said, eXp Realty does provide FREE access to over 4,000 Regus office business lounges worldwide. But if you thrive on having a salaried position with a traditional brokerage structure, Redfin might be the better option for you.

That income doesn’t end when you retire and it’s willable, so it continues to roll in even after you’re no longer working. Now that’s a win-win!

When comparing eXp Realty and Redfin, it really comes down to what you’re looking for in a brokerage. eXp Realty stands out with its high commission splits, lower fees, cutting-edge tech, and 24/7 support. Why Your Brokerage Choice Matters

Picking the right brokerage isn’t just about how much commission you get to keep—though, yes, that’s huge. Your brokerage shapes your daily experience, from the support you receive to the resources you can access. The right brokerage can make your business thrive, while the wrong one will slow you down.

Today, we’re comparing eXp Realty and Century 21. We’ll cover everything from commission splits and fees to training and agent satisfaction. With eXp Realty, everything is laid out clearly, but with Century 21, we had to do some digging to get all the details.

eXp Realty vs Century 21: Agent Satisfaction

Let’s kick things off by checking how happy agents are at each brokerage—because if the agents are satisfied, that’s a good sign. On Glassdoor, eXp Realty holds a solid 4.6-star rating, while Century 21 comes in at 4.2 stars.

Agent reviews often reflect how much support they’re getting, the resources available, and whether the brokerage sets them up for success. If you’re curious about how the top real estate firms stack up, check out our blog “12 Insider Picks for the Best Real Estate Brokerage in 2024!”. Spoiler alert: eXp Realty ranks #1 on Glassdoor.

eXp Realty vs Century 21: Brokerage Profitability

Why should you care about brokerage profitability? Because a brokerage that’s financially stable is less likely to make cuts that could hurt you or your clients.

Century 21 is part of Anywhere Real Estate, which also includes Sotheby’s, Better Homes & Gardens, Berkshire Hathaway, and Corcoran. Anywhere has posted 20 quarters of earnings, with 12 quarters of profits, so they’ve been profitable 60% of the time.

eXp Realty, on the other hand, has posted 20 quarters of earnings, with 15 quarters of profits, meaning they’ve been profitable 75% of the time. And eXp Realty is the only publicly traded brokerage that’s been profitable for the last five years. This financial stability leads to consistent improvements for agents and clients alike.

So if you’re looking for a brokerage that’s not only growing but also reinvesting in its agents, eXp Realty is the clear winner. If you want the full scoop on brokerage profitability, check out our blog “Top Real Estate Companies That Might Go Under!”.

eXp Realty vs Century 21: Commission Splits

Alright, let’s get into the commission splits—the part every agent wants to know. At Century 21, commission splits range from 70/30 to 92/8, and some offices may offer a cap, typically around $22,500, but you’ll need to check with your local office because, like many traditional brokerages, the split can vary depending on the office and the deal you negotiate.

Over at eXp Realty, the splits are straightforward. Every agent starts with an 80/20 split, and once you’ve paid $16,000 to the brokerage, you move to 100% commission for the rest of the year.

Plus, eXp Realty rewards agents with stock for hitting certain milestones, so you can earn even more than 100%. And what’s great is that eXp Realty offers the same split to every agent, no matter where you’re located—no haggling or mystery. It’s just transparent and fair across the board.

eXp Realty vs Century 21: E&O Insurance

Next up, Errors and Omissions (E&O) insurance—a must-have for every agent, as it protects both you and your brokerage from potential legal claims.

At Century 21, the details about E&O insurance are not readily available, and costs can vary significantly by office. It’s best to check with your local office since these fees can sometimes be pretty hefty.

At eXp Realty, the E&O insurance is predictable. Agents pay $60 per transaction, and once you’ve paid $750 for the year, you’re done. After that, no more E&O fees for the rest of the year, no matter how many deals you close. This is a huge advantage, especially if you’re just starting out and don’t want to deal with high upfront costs.

eXp Realty vs Century 21: Fees

Let’s talk about fees—because we all know they can eat into your bottom line if you’re not careful.

At eXp Realty, the fees are simple and predictable. Agents pay a $85 monthly fee and a $25 transaction fee until they cap. Super straightforward.

At Century 21, the fees are more varied. Depending on the office, agents could pay anywhere from $0 to $350 per month, plus there’s a 6% to 7% royalty fee due per transaction. In some cases, agents are still required to pay that royalty fee even after capping.

Plus, there are $499 transaction fees in some locations. You’ll need to check with your local office for the exact numbers, but overall, Century 21’s fees can add up faster than you might expect.

eXp Realty vs Century 21: Training and Support

Whether you’re new or experienced, training and support are essential to your success.

At eXp Realty, you’ve got access to 50+ live training sessions every week, as well as an entire on-demand library of courses. New agents can benefit from the Fast Start program, while experienced agents can level up with the Kick Start program. And if you ever need help, eXp Realty offers 24/7 support and over 2,000 full-time staff members ready to assist.

At Century 21, the training and support vary greatly by office. Some locations offer solid resources, while others might leave you wanting more. Your level of support really depends on how involved your local broker is, and the training is often up to the individual office.

If consistent, high-quality training and 24/7 support are important to you, eXp Realty comes out on top.

eXp Realty vs Century 21: Technology and Resources

Having the right tools can make all the difference in your real estate career, so let’s look at what these brokerages offer in terms of technology.

eXp Realty leads the charge in tech innovation. With a fully virtual brokerage model, agents work in eXp World, a metaverse-like platform where you can meet with your broker, attend trainings, and get tech support. Want the full scoop? Check out our blog on eXp World!

Plus, eXp Realty offers agents a personal IDX website, a robust kvCORE CRM, and a marketing center with customizable templates for all your agent marketing needs and even much more tech and resources.

Details on Century 21’s technology and resources are a little harder to come by. It seems to vary by office. So if tech is a priority for you, eXp Realty has the advantage.

Why Century 21 May Be Best for You

While eXp Realty offers a lot of advantages, there are still reasons why Century 21 might be the right fit for you. If you’re someone who prefers a more traditional brokerage experience, with physical offices and a broker that helps keep you on track, then Century 21 could be what you’re looking for.

But, if your attraction to an office is just because you want out of your house, eXp Realty does provide FREE access to over 4,000 Regus office business lounges around the globe. Still, if you need that in-person accountability and thrive in a structured office setting, Century 21 might suit your style better.

eXp’s Exclusive Resources

Beyond all the usual perks, eXp Realty brings some truly standout features that most other brokerages just can’t match. If you work in the luxury market, eXp’s Luxury Division gives your high-end listings global exposure, putting them in front of the right audience worldwide.

They’ve also got a team called Revenos, whose whole job is to find and deliver quality leads straight to eXp agents—pretty awesome, right?

Their Referral tool makes sending referrals to other agents a breeze, and for those who want to focus solely on referrals, eXp’s Referral Division helps cut costs while keeping you in the business.

And let’s not forget Revenue Share, where you can earn extra income by simply recommending agents to join eXp. That income doesn’t just stop when you retire and it’s willable, meaning it keeps coming even after you’re gone. It’s a win all around!

That’s a Wrap

When it comes to choosing between eXp Realty and Century 21, it really comes down to what you need in a brokerage.

eXp Realty offers more transparency, lower fees, and a fully virtual model that provides 24/7 support and cutting-edge technology. Century 21, on the other hand, offers a more traditional experience with physical offices and a recognizable brand, but it comes with higher fees and less consistent support.

title: 10 Real Estate Agent Marketing Mistakes You Need to Fix
excerpt: Hey agents, here’s your one-stop shop to walk you through real estate agent marketing mistakes that you need to end right now! These mishaps are…
content:
Hey agents, here’s your one-stop shop to walk you through real estate agent marketing mistakes that you need to end right now! These mishaps are often the difference between a closed deal and a missed opportunity. Nailing that first impression is everything in real estate, and knowing the common slip-ups can save you a lot of grief.

This blog is packed with 10 real estate agent marketing mistakes and how to repair them. We’ll count these huge mistakes down to the biggest mistakes you must fix today! Here’s your handy dandy index:

  • Branding Mistakes
  • Website Marketing Flaws
  • Social Media Marketing Flaws
  • Overlooking Customer Insights
  • Missed Opportunities to Retarget
  • Ineffective Data Management
  • Sales Overdrive
  • Slow Engagement Response
  • Setting Unrealistic Goals
  • Not Learning from Mistakes
  • That’s a Wrap
  • Join our FREE Team at eXp Realty
  • Frequently Asked Questions

Ok, let the countdown begin!

10. Branding Mistakes

Tackling branding and personalization real estate agent marketing mistakes with a thoughtful, consistent approach will elevate your marketing efforts.

Undefined Online Identity

Your online identity is your digital handshake. If you’re not telling your brand story clearly, you’re just another face in the crowd. Make sure you’re shouting from the rooftops—well, websites and social media—what makes you the go-to agent.

This isn’t just about logos and colors; it’s about weaving your unique promise into every post and page. That way, clients won’t just see you; they’ll see why they should choose you.

Lack of Personal Connection

Remember, real estate isn’t just property transactions. It’s about connecting dreams with reality. If you’re just listing specs and prices, you’re missing the heart of the business. Share your journey, the successes of your clients, and why you’re passionate about homes. Get personal!

Inconsistent Messaging

Consistency is king in digital communication. If your online voice keeps changing, it’s like wearing a disguise every time you meet someone. Avoid this real estate agent marketing mistake by using a content calendar to plan your posts, ensuring each one aligns with your brand’s voice and values. Plus, a calendar helps you stay ahead of your needs, easing your stress level a bit!

9. Website Marketing Flaws

When it comes to marketing, even minor technical errors can cost real estate agents big time. Here’s how to tackle these common real estate agent marketing mistakes head-on:

Avoid SEO Slip-Ups

SEO (Search Engine Optimization) is your best friend in the digital age, especially if you’re a real estate agent looking to get noticed. Start by peppering your website with the right keywords to climb up those Google ranks. And don’t forget, a lot of your potential clients are scrolling on their smartphones, so make sure your site looks great and functions smoothly on mobile devices too. Keep your blog fresh and filled with keyword-rich real estate articles to pull in more traffic.

Web Design Woes

Your website is like your online open house. Make sure it’s inviting and easy to navigate so visitors can find exactly what they need without hassle. Every page should guide them on what to do next, whether it’s calling for more info or signing up for your newsletter. Website speed is also key— a slow-loading site could make visitors bounce faster than you can say “new listing!”

Underused Video Content

If a picture is worth a thousand words, a video must be priceless! Boost your listings with video tours to draw in buyers. Consider tapping into the power of live video on social media to engage with potential clients in real-time.

Also, create helpful explainer videos for buyers and sellers to demystify the real estate process. For that, make a list of what you find yourself explaining over and over again. Customers will value your efforts, and, hey, you’ll save loads of time by not needing to constantly repeat that information.

8. Social Media Marketing Flaws

Let’s get into two super common social media real estate agent marketing mistakes that you must avoid.

Quantity vs Quality

One mistake is preferring volume over value in your marketing efforts. Here’s a tip: flooding your audience with constant posts isn’t as effective as sharing genuinely impactful content intermittently.

I know! We’re all trained to believe that more content is better. We fear that algorithms won’t reward our content if we aren’t putting out tons of content.

But, that’s not the case. Focus on crafting content that truly resonates—like detailed guides that answer the big questions for buyers and sellers. This type of content sticks in their minds and is more likely to be shared, amplifying your reach organically.

Of course, the proof is in the pudding. Always measure your efforts by tracking the return on investment (ROI). This ensures your marketing isn’t just busy work, but is genuinely building your business.

Forgetting Audience Engagement

Now let’s jump to a classic real estate agent marketing mistake: neglecting audience engagement. I know, it can be tough. Sometimes finding your audience’s comments takes some effort because not every platform is easy to navigate. Also, sometimes the comments are negative or full of vendors wanting to sell you their wares.

But, it’s important to take the time to find and read your audience’s comments and respond promptly. Turn all interactions into an opportunity to get to know the commenter and move your business forward. Here are some tips on how to make all engagement useful:

Genuine Customer Comments

This is why you’re providing content. It’s what’s what you want to see. Take the time needed to respond to potential client comments thoughtfully. Craft a lengthier comment if that’s what the comment deserves. Ask questions to keep the engagement going.

Haters

Yep, eventually, we all get these. You know, those people who just can’t resist throwing out some unsolicited negativity. Don’t fear these comments or delete them. Instead, respond professionally to demonstrate who you are to your “real” prospects and to extend the engagement for algorithms to pick up and reward.

Vendors

Yep, even those trying to sell you something can boost your algorithm gold stars. Engage with them. And here’s a little secret: your engagement can be more than just saying you’re not interested. Ask them how they specifically plan to help you. You might pick up a useful tip or two.

Bottom line, no matter what type of comment, engagement shows you’re attentive and caring boosts your brand’s human touch. By avoiding this common real estate agent marketing mistake, you’ll forge deeper connections that are more likely to convert into lasting client relationships.

7. Overlooking Customer Insights

One of the big real estate agent marketing mistakes is ignoring the gold mine found in customer feedback. When clients offer advice, smart agents don’t just listen. They act. Implementing client feedback, even minor suggestions, can drastically refine your approach.

How do you get the feedback? Consider a survey after a deal. Encourage your clients to share their opinions on anything that could improve future client experiences. Let them know you’re genuinely interested in their feedback.

If you have a social media presence, use the feedback you already have at your fingertips – your analytics. You know, all that free information sitting in our accounts that we rarely look at? Review it now because those analytics offer insights into what works. Focus on which posts resonate the most and use this data to shape your content strategy.

Now for the frosting on the cake! Make changes based on what you learn and tell your clients and potential clients about it! Sharing how you’ve evolved your services based on client input demonstrates responsiveness and underscores your dedication to client satisfaction. That’s some good optics!

6. Missed Opportunities to Retarget

Another major real estate agent marketing mistake is missing opportunities to retarget. Don’t let potential clients slip through the cracks! You’ve already done the work coming up with great ads. Retargeting those ads is a fantastic way to reel back those who visited your site but left without engaging.

One effective way to do this is through Facebook’s pixel-based ads, which track visitors and show them relevant ads later. For example, if a visitor browses a property listing, a retargeting ad can remind them of that listing, keeping your services top of mind.

Creating list-based retargeting ads can also be effective. Uploading a list of potential leads to Facebook lets you target ads directly to those users, increasing the chance they’ll come back (Constant Contact). Regularly track and adjust your retargeting strategy to ensure it’s effective, and consider setting up A/B tests to see which ads perform best

5. Ineffective Data Management

A robust CRM (Customer Relationship Management) tool isn’t just helpful; it’s critical. Using a CRM helps keep track of all your leads and your interactions with those leads, all in one place. This ensures you don’t miss any opportunities.

As all working agents know, managing prospect and client information and interactions without a CRM becomes downright chaotic. That leads to missed follow-ups and lost sales.

And, remember, regularly clean your data by removing outdated or incorrect information to keep your database accurate. Outdated data wastes your time and effort.

4. Sales Overdrive

Let’s get real. Sometimes, in the rush to get a client, you might come off a bit too strong. That eager beaver act? That’s a real estate agent marketing mistake that can scare off potential clients.

Instead of going full throttle on the sales pitch, focus on building trust first. Do that by showcasing testimonials in all your marketing. Create a title for your happy client comments so that new potential clients can easily scan for what’s most important to them.

For example, these are some titles to go with the testimonial that follows it:

  • Attentive and Supportive: My agent was attentive throughout the entire home-buying process. It seemed she wasn’t just about closing a deal, she was part of the journey with us.
  • Navigating Competitive Markets: Our agent found a hidden gem in a competitive market and negotiated the price down by 5%.
  • Stress-Free Selling: My agent’s compassion and expertise took the stress out of selling my family home.
  • First-Time Buyer Success: My agent patiently explained every step of the process and was always available to answer questions.

By showcasing client satisfaction and successful outcomes, you create a relatable and reassuring image that attracts more clients naturally.

3. Slow Engagement Response

Yes, speed is everything in prospect and client communications! Monitor your messages and emails closely and respond as quickly as possible. Fast replies demonstrate your commitment to excellent customer service. Slow replies tell clients that you are too busy to meet their needs.

What if you can’t always keep a close eye out? Consider setting up carefully crafted automated responses for common inquiries to ensure potential clients get answers promptly. This keeps them less likely to look for a prompt response elsewhere.

2. Setting Unrealistic Goals

Many real estate agents aim high, but setting sky-high goals without grounding them in reality is like setting sail without a compass. It’s vital to set realistic targets that align with what’s typical in the real estate market. To help you set achievable goals, here are a few strategies and examples:

Break Down annual Goals into Manageable Tasks

Set specific annual goals, like increasing your annual commission by selling one more home per month than last year. This can give you a clear target and a sense of direction.

Break down these annual goals into monthly or weekly tasks. For instance, aim to hold two open houses per week or send out 20 handwritten cards to your sphere of influence and network each week

Implement SMART Goals

Use the SMART (Specific, Measurable, Achievable, Relevant, Time-bound) framework to set clear and realistic goals. For example, host a homebuyers event each quarter or complete a certain number of CE credit hours by a specific date.

This approach ensures your goals are ambitious, grounded in reality and trackable.

Regularly Monitor and Adjust Goals

Keep track of your progress with tools like Google Docs or a CRM system. Regularly reviewing your goals helps you stay on track and make necessary adjustments.

Periodically analyze your performance to identify areas to improve or to adjust strategies if you’re not hitting your targets.

Focus on Building Habits

Rather than solely focusing on outcomes, concentrate on and celebrate good habits. For example, make it a habit to call prospects daily or to post one YouTube video per week. Celebrate these small wins along the way to stay positive and motivated. This will help you keep pushing towards your larger goals.

Stay Accountable

Stay accountable by sharing your goals with a mentor, broker, or friend. Better yet, partner up with a peer who also needs accountability and work to keep each other accountable.

By setting realistic and manageable goals, you will build towards long-term success. You’ll stay on track and continue to grow your business effectively.

1. Not Learning from Mistakes

Yep, this is the number one real estate agent marketing mistake! Mistakes aren’t just mishaps. Mistakes are learning opportunities, like stepping stones to mastery. Every missed target or campaign hiccup is a lesson in disguise. Here’s how you can turn those slip-ups into success stories:

Embrace a Growth Mindset

Adopt a mindset where mistakes are viewed as opportunities for learning rather than failures. This mindset fosters resilience and continuous improvement. So, the next time you make a mistake say to yourself “in the lesson, find the gift.” That gift will make every day thereafter more effective.

Document Lessons Learned

Maintain a “lessons learned” log. Documenting what worked and what didn’t helps avoid repeating the same mistakes. For example, if a particular type of social media post gets little engagement, note that down and try a different approach next time

Actively learning from mistakes makes all the difference. There is always something to be learned and improved if you take the time to figure it out and make the needed changes.

That’s a Wrap

You’ve seen the pitfalls. Real estate agent marketing mistakes are many and they are tricky. But, knowing what to dodge makes you smarter. Let’s make those lessons count towards your success.

For more, be sure to read our next blog because we’ll expose the number one marketing secret to totally ramp up your results. Best yet – you can use it in with every type of marketing you do!

And that’s just the beginning! Explore more about our robust team benefits.

Don’t let this opportunity pass you by. Transform your real estate career, maximize your income, and secure your future. Contact us now to schedule a video consultation or email us at team@SmartAgentAlliance.com. We’re here to ensure your success.

How can a real estate agent best use testimonials?
